column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2

#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=WHEREIN EDITH CARR WAGES A BATTLE , AND HART HENDERSON STANDS GUARD

#Text=Many people looked , a few followed , when Edith Carr slowly came down the main street of Mackinac , pausing here and there to note the glow of colour in one small booth after another , overflowing with gay curios .

#Text=That street of packed white sand , winding with the curves of the shore , outlined with brilliant shops , and thronged with laughing , bare-headed people in outing costumes was a picturesque and fascinating sight .
#Text=Thousands annually made long journeys and paid exorbitant prices to take part in that pageant .
#Text=As Edith Carr passed , she was the most distinguished figure of the old street .
#Text=Her clinging black gown was sufficiently elaborate for a dinner dress .
#Text=On her head was a large , wide , drooping-brimmed black hat , with immense floating black plumes , while on the brim , and among the laces on her breast glowed velvety , deep red roses .
#Text=Some way these made up for the lack of colour in her cheeks and lips , and while her eyes seemed unnaturally bright , to a close observer they appeared weary .
#Text=Despite the effort she made to move lightly she was very tired , and dragged her heavy feet with an effort .
#Text=She turned at the little street leading to the dock , and went to meet the big lake steamer ploughing up the Straits from Chicago .
#Text=Past the landing place , on to the very end of the pier she went , then sat down , leaned against a dock support and closed her tired eyes .
#Text=When the steamer came very close she languidly watched the people lining the railing .
#Text=Instantly she marked one lean anxious face turned toward hers , and with a throb of pity she lifted a hand and waved to Hart Henderson .
#Text=He was the first man to leave the boat , coming to her instantly .
#Text=She spread her trailing skirts and motioned him to sit beside her .
#Text=Silently they looked across the softly lapping water .
#Text=At last she forced herself to speak to him .
#Text=“ Did you have a successful trip ? ”
#Text=“ I accomplished my purpose . ”
#Text=“ You did n't lose any time getting back . ”
#Text=“ I never do when I am coming to you . ”
#Text=“ Do you want to go to the cottage for anything ? ”
#Text=“ No. ”
#Text=“ Then let us sit here and wait until the Petoskey steamer comes in .
#Text=I like to watch the boats .
#Text=Sometimes I study the faces , if I am not too tired . ”
#Text=“ Have you seen any new types to-day ? ”
#Text=She shook her head .
#Text=“ This has not been an easy day , Hart . ”
#Text=“ And it 's going to be worse , ” said Henderson bitterly .
#Text=“ There 's no use putting it off .
#Text=Edith , I saw some one to-day . ”
#Text=“ You should have seen thousands , ” she said lightly .
#Text=“ I did .
#Text=But of them all , only one will be of interest to you . ”
#Text=“ Man or woman ? ”
#Text=“ Man . ”
#Text=“ Where ? ”
#Text=“ Lake Shore private hospital . ”
#Text=“ An accident ? ”
#Text=“ No. Nervous and physical breakdown . ”
#Text=“ Phil said he was going back to the Limberlost . ”
#Text=“ He went .
#Text=He was there three weeks , but the strain broke him .
#Text=He has an old letter in his hands that he has handled until it is ragged .
#Text=He held it up to me and said : ' You can see for yourself that she says she will be well and happy , but we ca n't know until we see her again , and that may never be .

#Text=She may have gone too near that place her father went down , some of that Limberlost gang may have found her in the forest , she may lie dead in some city morgue this instant , waiting for me to find her body . ' ”
#Text=“ Hart !
#Text=For pity sake stop ! ”
#Text=“ I ca n't , ” cried Henderson desperately .
#Text=“ I am forced to tell you .
#Text=They are fighting brain fever .
#Text=He did go back to the swamp and he prowled it night and day .
#Text=The days down there are hot now , and the nights wet with dew and cold .
#Text=He paid no attention and forgot his food .
#Text=A fever started and his uncle brought him home .
#Text=They 've never had a word from her , or found a trace of her .
#Text=Mrs. Comstock thought she had gone to O'Mores ' at Great Rapids , so when Phil broke down she telegraphed there .
#Text=They had been gone all summer , so her mother is as anxious as Phil . ”
#Text=“ The O'Mores are here , ” said Edith .
#Text=“ I have n't seen any of them , because I have n't gone out much in the few days since we came , but this is their summer home . ”
#Text=“ Edith , they say at the hospital that it will take careful nursing to save Phil .
#Text=He is surrounded by stacks of maps and railroad guides .
#Text=He is trying to frame up a plan to set the entire detective agency of the country to work .
#Text=He says he will stay there just two days longer .
#Text=The doctors say he will kill himself when he goes .
#Text=He is a sick man , Edith .
#Text=His hands are burning and shaky and his breath was hot against my face . ”
#Text=“ Why are you telling me ? ”
#Text=It was a cry of acute anguish .
#Text=“ He thinks you know where she is . ”
#Text=“ I do not !
#Text=I have n't an idea !
#Text=I never dreamed she would go away when she had him in her hand !
#Text=I should not have done it ! ”
#Text=“ He said it was something you said to her that made her go . ”
#Text=“ That may be , but it does n't prove that I know where she went . ”
